Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: High-Resolution Underway Air-Sea Observations in Drake Passage for Climate Science
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Drake Passage is the body of water between South America and the Western Antarctic Peninsula, thus connecting the Southern Atlantic and Southern Pacific Oceans through the unimpeded flow of the immense Antarctic Circumpolar Current (ACC).

Using the relatively frequent ferry crossings of the Drake Passage by the RV/AS LMGould, the USAP supply ship, this proposal will continue the of collection of upper ocean XBT temperature and XTCD salinity data in this natural chokepoint for the ACC. This will yield additional hydrographic observations on seasonal to interannual timescales, and on spatial scales ranging from the current core to mesoscale eddies. These high-resolution, multi-repeat transects (up to 6 ~7 crossings per year) are quality controlled, archived and made available to the broader community in order to facilitate study of the modes of variability of the dominant oceanic current on the planet (the ACC). The Drake Passage XBT/XCTD transect time series now extends back to 1996, and continues to add to a number of quantitative estimates of the long term trends in Southern Ocean fronts, surface water mass properties, their response to atmospheric forcing on climate relevant time scales. This proposal also seeks renewal of a near decadal time series effort measuring the underway surface partial pressure of carbon dioxide (pCO2) in regular transects across the Drake Passage.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Antarctic continent is encircled by the Antarctic Circumpolar Current (ACC) and effectively isolated from warmer latitudes closer to the Equator. Upwelling of deep waters occurs throughout the ACC with important consequences for ocean carbon cycling and marine biological production. The path of the ACC is narrowest through the Drake Passage, a 780 km gap between Antarctica and the southern tip of South America. The Drake Passage Time-series (DPT) takes advantage of the regular transits of the Antarctic Research Supply Vessel (ARSV) Laurence M. Gould across the Drake Passage to assess spatial and temporal variability in the biogeochemistry of the ACC region with the ultimate goal of understanding the role of the Southern Ocean in the global carbon cycle. The major contributions of this study during the grant period from September 1, 2014 to August 31, 2016 are as follows:

 

1. Observations: The DPT made more than 122,000 measurements of the partial pressure of carbon dioxide (CO2) in surface water (pCO2surf) over the two-year grant period. Over 37,000 of these pCO2surf measurements were made during the cold months of May through October when conditions in the Southern Ocean are harsh. Winter measurements are vitally important because of historical under-sampling and because biogeochemical fluxes are potentially large during this period. Over the two-year grant period, discrete surface water samples for macronutrients, total CO2 (TCO2), and the stable carbon isotopic composition of TCO2 (T13CO2) were collected on thirteen crossings of the Drake Passage; six of these crossings occurred from May through October. These measurements provide full characterization of the carbonate system and allow estimation of biological production and uptake of anthropogenic CO2. On the other side of the air-sea interface, the atmospheric O2/CO2 measurement system provides observations that enhance understanding of large-scale processes controlling surface fluxes of CO2 in the Southern Ocean due to the more expansive footprint of the lower atmosphere compared to the surface ocean. Two full seasonal cycles of atmospheric O2/CO2 were captured over this grant period. All ocean and atmosphere observations are quality-controlled and submitted to databases that allow the data to be utilized by the larger research community.

 

2. Ocean uptake of CO2: Several studies completed during the grant period aimed at quantifying and understanding mechanistic controls on the uptake of CO2 by the Southern Ocean. One study used the DPT data combined with all other available pCO2surf data to understand how ocean uptake of CO2 has varied over the entire mid and high latitude Southern Hemisphere oceans over the past 30 years. This study shows an increase in ocean CO2 uptake over the last 10 years beyond the increase expected due to increased CO2 emissions. This period of strengthening CO2 uptake followed a period where Southern Ocean CO2 uptake appeared to be stagnating. An analysis of just the DPT data over the length of the time-series (2002-present) also suggests increasing CO2 uptake and indicates that the change in air-sea CO2 uptake rates over the last decade is most pronounced in austral winter south of the Antarctic Polar Front due in part to upwelling of deep waters with low anthropogenic CO2. An analysis of the change in T13CO2 since 2005 from the DPT compared to the decadal rate of change observed for regions further west suggests that there may be a gradient in CO2 uptake across the Pacific sector of the Southern Ocean with the highest uptake observed closer to the Drake Passage. Still another study examined pCO2surf variability associated with mesoscale eddies.

 

3. Biogeochemical controls on pCO2surf: A central focus of the DPT continues to be quantifying the influence of biological productivity on air-sea CO2 flux. A recent study examined the relationship between surface ocean dissolved O2 and pCO2surf comparing the less productive waters of the Drake Passage with the highly productive waters off the Western Antarctic Peninsula which are sampled every year as part of the Palmer Long Term Ecological Research project. This analysis also quantified the impact of physical versus biological processes in controlling dissolved O2 and pCO2surf in different regions from the marginal ice zone to the open Southern Ocean.
